label: def-mean-field-phase-space
nl_definition: The single-particle phase space $\Omega$ is the Cartesian product of the valid position domain $X_{\text{valid}} \subset \mathbb{R}^d$ and the allowed velocity domain $V_{\text{alg}} \subset \mathbb{R}^d$.

formal_conditions.text: The single-particle phase space, denoted $\Omega$, is the Cartesian product of the valid position and velocity domains:
$X_{\text{valid}}$ is a bounded, convex domain with a $C^2$ boundary.
formal_conditions.latex: X_{\text{valid}} \subset \mathbb{R}^d \text{ is bounded, convex, with } \partial X_{\text{valid}} \text{ being } C^2

formal_conditions.text: $V_{\text{alg}}$ is the closed ball of allowed velocities.

properties.name: Completeness
properties.description: Defines the complete set of possible kinematic states (position and velocity) a particle can occupy.

properties.name: Constraint Dependence
properties.description: Its properties are a direct translation of the constraints imposed on walkers in the Euclidean Gas algorithm.

parameters.description: The bounded, convex domain for position.
The closed ball of allowed velocities.

label: def-phase-space-density
nl_definition: The phase-space sub-probability density $f(t,z)$ describes the state of the alive population in the swarm at time $t$, where the integral of $f$ over any region $A \subseteq \Omega$ yields the expected mass of alive walkers in that region.

formal_conditions.text: The domain and codomain of $f$.
The mass of alive walkers in $A$ is given by the integral:
The total mass of alive walkers $m_a(t)$ is the integral over the entire phase space $\Omega$, which is bounded by 1.

properties.name: Mass Interpretation
properties.description: Integrating $f(t, \cdot, \cdot)$ over a subset $A \subseteq \Omega$ yields the expected fraction of alive walkers whose state $(x,v)$ falls into $A$ at time $t$.

properties.name: Total Mass Constraint
properties.description: The total mass of alive walkers, $m_a(t)$, cannot exceed 1.

parameters.description: A measurable subset of the phase space $\Omega$.
A point in the phase space, $z=(x,v)$.

notes.text: The integral of $f$ over phase space gives the total mass of alive walkers, $m_a(t)$, and the remaining mass $m_d(t) = 1 - m_a(t)$ is the mass of dead walkers.
The evolution of the system is described by a coupled system for $f(t,z)$ and $m_d(t)$ that conserves the total mass $m_a(t) + m_d(t) = 1$.

label: def-mean-field-moments
nl_definition: The Mean-Field Statistical Moments ($\mu_R[f], \sigma_R^2[f], \mu_D[f], \sigma_D^2[f]$) are specific functionals of the phase-space density $f(t,z)$, computed by taking expected values over the normalized density $f(t,z)/m_a(t)$, where $m_a(t)$ is the total alive mass.

formal_conditions.text: Total alive mass:
Mean Reward Moment
Reward Variance Moment
Mean Distance Moment
Distance Variance Moment

parameters.description: Variance of reward functional at time $t$
Distance metric in space $\mathcal{Y}$ (likely related to particle positions)
Mapping from phase space $z$ to position space (implied)
Variance of distance functional at time $t$

notes.text: These moments arise in the standardization pipeline, replacing empirical statistics computed over a finite set of alive walkers in the N-particle system.
The notation $\mu[f]$ emphasizes dependence on the entire shape of the function $f$.

label: def-mean-field-patched-std
nl_definition: The Mean-Field Regularized Standard Deviations ($\widehat{\sigma}_R[f](t)$ and $\widehat{\sigma}_D[f](t)$) are functionals of the density $f$, obtained by applying a regularized standard deviation function ($\sigma'_{\text{reg}}$) to the mean-field variance functionals ($\sigma_R^2[f](t)$ and $\sigma_D^2[f](t)$).

notes.text: Ensures numerical stability and continuity by preventing denominators from approaching zero when the true variance $\sigma^2[f]$ is close to zero.

label: def-mean-field-z-scores
nl_definition: The mean-field Z-scores, $\widetilde{r}$ for a raw measurement $R$ and $\widetilde{d}$ for a raw distance $d$, standardize these measurements using global, density-dependent moments ($\mu$ and $\widehat{\sigma}$) derived from functionals related to $f$.

formal_conditions.text: Mean-field Z-score for measurement R
Mean-field Z-score for measurement d

properties.name: Standardization
properties.description: The scores standardize the raw inputs using global, density-dependent moments.

properties.name: Inputs
properties.description: Depends on the particle state $z$, companion state $z_c$, time $t$, and a functional context $f$.

parameters.description: Raw measurement R at state z
Global mean of R at time t
Global standard deviation of R at time t
Raw distance measurement between transformed states
Global mean of d at time t
Global standard deviation of d at time t

notes.text: These scores are the first step in constructing the final, non-linear fitness potential.

label: def-mean-field-fitness-potential
nl_definition: A functional $V[f](z, z_c, t)$ of the density $f$ that multiplicatively combines rescaled diversity ($\widetilde{d}$) and reward ($\widetilde{r}$) components, modulated by parameters $\alpha, \beta, \eta$.

formal_conditions.text: The Mean-Field Fitness Potential is constructed by applying the canonical `Rescale Transformation` $g_A$ to the mean-field Z-scores:

properties.name: Type
properties.description: A functional of the density $f$, denoted $V[f]$.

properties.name: Structure
properties.description: Combines contributions from the reward and diversity channels multiplicatively.

properties.name: Purpose
properties.description: Balances the drive for high rewards (exploitation) with the need to maintain diversity (exploration).

parameters.description: The Mean-Field Fitness Potential, a functional of the density $f$ that determines the fitness of a particle at state $z$ relative to a companion at $z_c$.
A small positive constant used in the transformation.
Exponent controlling the contribution of the diversity channel.
Exponent controlling the contribution of the reward channel.

notes.text: The structure allows the algorithm to balance the drive for high rewards (exploitation) with the need to maintain diversity (exploration).

label: def-baoab-update-rule
nl_definition: The BAOAB method defines a five-step algorithm for updating the state $(x, v)$ of a particle under a system described by an SDE, splitting the dynamics into force kicks (B), position drift (A), and an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process for velocity (O).

formal_conditions.text: B-Step (Force Kick): Velocity update using half-step force kick.
A-Step (Position Drift): Position update using the intermediate velocity.
O-Step (Ornstein-Uhlenbeck): Full-step velocity update incorporating friction and thermal noise.
A-Step (Position Drift): Final position update.
B-Step (Force Kick): Final velocity update using force at the new position.

properties.name: Symmetry
properties.description: The method is composed symmetrically from analytically solvable parts (B and A steps sandwiching the O step).

properties.name: Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Step
properties.description: Step 3 exactly solves the velocity update governed by friction ($\gamma_{\mathrm{fric}}$) and thermal noise ($\Theta$).

parameters.description: Position of the particle at time $t_n$
Velocity of the particle at time $t_n$
Position of the particle at time $t_{n+1}$
Velocity of the particle at time $t_{n+1}$
Friction coefficient for the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process
Temperature parameter for the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process
Flow field evaluated at position $x$, related to friction/noise

notes.text: This rule applies for a single particle state update from time $t_n$ to $t_{n+1} = t_n + \tau$.

Parameters are assumed to be defined in the Euclidean Gas specification, which includes $W_t$ as a standard Wiener process (though the Wiener process itself is only implicitly relevant via the SDE solved).

label: def-kinetic-generator
nl_definition: The Kinetic Transport Operator ($\mathcal{L}_{\text{kin}}$) is the infinitesimal generator of the Fokker-Planck equation governing the N-particle kinetic evolution of alive walkers under the corresponding underdamped Langevin SDEs, subject to reflecting boundary conditions on position and velocity.

properties.name: Type
properties.description: Infinitesimal generator (operator) for the kinetic stage of the dynamics.

properties.name: Applicability
properties.description: Applies to the set of alive walkers $\mathcal{A}$.

properties.name: Boundary Conditions
properties.description: Subject to reflecting boundary conditions on both position ($\partial X_{\text{valid}}$) and velocity (velocity ball $V_{\text{alg}}$).

parameters.description: Force acting on walker i at position x_i
Mass of the walker (implied by context, though not explicitly defined as a parameter in the SDE)
Drift velocity field dependent on position x_i
Test function on the swarm state space

notes.text: The BAOAB integrator is a discrete-time approximation of the underlying SDE.

label: def-killing-operator
nl_definition: The interior killing operator is implicitly defined by the killing rate $c(z)f(z)$ applied to the density $f$. The total mass killed per unit time by this operator is given by the functional $k_{\text{killed}}[f](t)$.

formal_conditions.text: The interior killing rate $c$ is a smooth, non-negative function.
Safety in the interior: $c(z) = 0$ for all $z$ in a safe subset of $\Omega$ away from the position boundary.
formal_conditions.latex: c(z) = 0 \text{ for } z \text{ away from boundary}

formal_conditions.text: Activity near the boundary: $c(z) > 0$ in a smooth transition layer near $\partial X_{\text{valid}} \times V_{\text{alg}}$.
Smoothness: $c \in C^\infty(\Omega)$.
The total mass killed per unit time functional:

properties.name: Rate Application
properties.description: Removes mass from the alive density $f$ at a rate proportional to $c(z)f(z)$.

properties.name: Killing Rate Properties
properties.description: The killing rate $c$ must be non-negative, smooth ($C^\infty$), and zero in the interior safe region.

parameters.description: The interior killing rate, a smooth, non-negative function.

notes.text: The interior killing operator models 'death' by removing mass from the density $f$ at a spatial rate determined by $c$.
The context relates this operator to PDE solutions where $f$ evolves over time $t$ in domain $\Omega$.

label: def-revival-operator
nl_definition: The Revival Operator $B[f, m_d](t, z)$ models the injection of mass from the dead population back into the alive population, defined proportionally to the normalized alive density $f(t,z)/m_a(t)$ multiplied by the total dead mass $m_d(t)$ and the revival rate $\lambda_{\text{revive}}$.

formal_conditions.text: The Revival Operator is defined as:
The total mass revived per unit time is:

properties.name: Spatial Profile
properties.description: The spatial profile of the re-injected mass is proportional to the current alive density, mirroring the discrete algorithm's revival mechanism.

parameters.description: the revival rate, a free parameter independent of the timestep (typical values: 0.1-5)
the current alive mass (implied by context $m_d(t) = 1 - m_a(t)$)

notes.text: Revival is modeled as a source term that re-injects mass from the dead population back into the alive population. The dead population acts as a reservoir from which revival occurs at a constant rate.
This form directly translates the discrete algorithm: dead walkers select companions uniformly from the alive set and clone to their positions.

label: def-cloning-generator
nl_definition: The Internal Cloning Operator, $S[f]$, is a mass-neutral, non-local operator representing the mean-field limit of a discrete cloning mechanism, defined as the difference between source ($S_{\text{src}}$) and sink ($S_{\text{sink}}$) terms involving the density $f$, cloning probability $P_{\text{clone}}$, and jitter kernel $Q_{\delta}$.

formal_conditions.text: The operator decomposes into sink and source terms.
formal_conditions.latex: S[f](t, z) = S_{\text{src}}[f](t, z) - S_{\text{sink}}[f](t, z)

formal_conditions.text: Sink term definition (mass removed).
Source term definition (mass gained).
formal_conditions.latex: S_{\text{src}}[f](t,z) = \frac{1}{\tau m_a(t)} \int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega} f(t,z_d) f(t,z_c) P_{\text{clone}}[f/m_a](z_d, z_c) Q_{\delta}(z \mid z_c) \,\mathrm{d}z_d\,\mathrm{d}z_c

formal_conditions.text: Mass neutrality condition (integration over the domain $\Omega$ yields zero).

parameters.description: The Internal Cloning Operator acting on the density function $f$.
The density function (or 'alive density') at time $t$ and position $z$.
Total mass at time $t$, often given by $\int_{\Omega} f(t,z) \,\mathrm{d}z$.
The spatial domain over which the walkers evolve.
The cloning probability kernel, dependent on the normalized alive density $f/m_a$.
The jitter kernel (Gaussian in position, delta in velocity) specifying where the offspring lands relative to the parent state $z_c$.
The discrete timestep, where $1/\tau$ converts per-step probabilities to continuous rates.

notes.text: $P_{\text{clone}}[f/m_a](z_d, z_c)$ is the cloning probability depending on fitness values computed from the normalized alive density $f/m_a$.
$Q_{\delta}(z \mid z_c)$ is the jitter kernel (Gaussian in position, delta in velocity).

label: def-transport-operator
nl_definition: The Transport Operator, $L^\dagger$, is the formal $L^2$-adjoint of the backward kinetic generator $L$, acting on a density $f$ as the negative divergence of the probability flux $J = (J_x, J_v)$.

formal_conditions.text:
$L^\dagger f = -
abla \cdot J[f] = -
abla_x \cdot J_x[f] - 
abla_v \cdot J_v[f]$
$J_x[f] := v f - D_x \nabla_x f$
$J_v[f] := A_v f - D_v \nabla_v f$

parameters.description: The backward kinetic generator from Section 2.2.
The density function on which the operator acts.

notes.text: The forward equation uses the formal adjoint of $\mathcal{L}_{\text{kin}}$, which is the Fokker-Planck operator.
